user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.14 is: The Standard Library function memcmp shall not be used to compare null terminated strings.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_hex_to_bin:
```c
size_t
MHD_hex_to_bin (const char *hex,
                size_t len,
                void *bin)
{
  uint8_t *const out = (uint8_t *) bin;
  size_t r;
  size_t w;

  if (0 == len)
    return 0;
  r = 0;
  w = 0;
  if (0 != len % 2)
  {
    /* Assume the first byte is encoded with single digit */
    const int l = toxdigitvalue (hex[r++]);
    if (0 > l)
      return 0;
    out[w++] = (uint8_t) ((unsigned int) l);
  }
  while (r < len)
  {
    const int h = toxdigitvalue (hex[r++]);
    const int l = toxdigitvalue (hex[r++]);
    if ((0 > h) || (0 > l))
      return 0;
    out[w++] = (uint8_t) ( ((uint8_t) (((uint8_t) ((unsigned int) h)) << 4))
                           | ((uint8_t) ((unsigned int) l)) );
  }
  mhd_assert (len == r);
  mhd_assert ((len + 1) / 2 == w);
  return w;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: I found no uses of memcmp (or other standard library string-comparison functions such as strcmp, strncmp, bcmp, or strcasecmp) in the provided MHD_hex_to_bin implementation. The function only calls toxdigitvalue (to parse individual hex digits) and mhd_assert, performs integer arithmetic and byte writes; there are no calls to the C standard library comparison functions nor any obvious indirect calls (function pointers) that would perform a memcmp. Therefore there are no code fragments in this function that need investigation for MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.14. If toxdigitvalue or mhd_assert are implemented elsewhere, those implementations would need to be checked separately for memcmp usage, but they are not part of the supplied code fragment and thus do not constitute suspicious fragments here.
